ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_0: Do you see any remnant of them left?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_1: Do you see any trace of them?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_2: Do you now see any trace of them?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_3: Can you see any of their survivors?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_4: So do you see any survivor among them?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_5: Do you see any remnants of them
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_6: Do you then see of them one remaining?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_7: Now dost thou see any remnant of them?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_8: Canst thou (O Muhammad) see any remnant of them?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_9: Do you see any vestige left of them now?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_10: Beholdest thou any of them remaining?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_11: So do you see any remaining trace of them?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_12: Then seest thou any of them left surviving?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_13: Do you see any remnants of them?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_14: Can you see any remnant of them now?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_15: Can you see any remnant of them?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_16: Then do you see of them any remains?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_17: [69:8] So do you see any remnant of them? (min bāqiyatin: this is either the adjectival qualification of an implicit nafs, ‘soul’, or the [final suffixed] tā’ is for hyperbole, in other words [understand it as fa-hal tarā lahum] min bāqin, ‘any one remaining?’ No!).
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_18: Canst thou (0 Muhammad) see any remnant of them?) He says: every single one of them was destroyed by the wind.
